member.name: M:VRage.Game.ModAPI.IMyCubeGrid.IsInSameLogicalGroupAs(VRage.Game.ModAPI.IMyCubeGrid)
member.summary: Determines whether this grid is in the same logical group as the other, meaning they're connected either mechanically or via blocks like connectors. Be aware that using merge blocks combines grids into one, so this function will not filter out grids connected that way.

summary.para: Determines whether this grid is mechanically connected to the other. This is any grid connected with rotors or pistons or other mechanical devices, but not things like connectors. This will in most cases constitute your complete construct.

Be aware that using merge blocks combines grids into one, so this function will not filter out grids connected that way. Also be aware that detaching the heads of pistons and rotors will cause this connection to change.

summary.para: Determines whether this grid is mechanically connected to the other. This is any grid connected with rotors or pistons or other mechanical devices, but not things like connectors. This will in most cases constitute your complete construct.

Be aware that using merge blocks combines grids into one, so this function will not filter out grids connected that way. Also be aware that detaching the heads of pistons and rotors will cause this connection to change.

Using MyIni to deal with internal storage:

member.name: T:VRage.Game.Entity.MyGameLogic
member.summary:
This is mostly a copy of the updating system present in MyEntities.
The old style of GameLogic component was tied to entity updates. This meant that when the entity removed one of its update flags, the component would stop updating with no warning.
Here we update GameLogic components separately from the containing entity.

member.name: M:VRage.Game.Entity.MyGameLogic.RegisterForUpdate(VRage.Game.Components.MyGameLogicComponent)

member.name: M:VRage.Game.Entity.MyGameLogic.UnregisterForUpdate(VRage.Game.Components.MyGameLogicComponent)
member.summary: Unregisters a component from the update system. Only use when disposing a component! If changing update flags, use ChangeUpdate!

member.name: M:VRage.Game.Entity.MyGameLogic.ChangeUpdate(VRage.Game.Components.MyGameLogicComponent,VRage.ModAPI.MyEntityUpdateEnum,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Modifies a component's update flags without modifying lists the component is already in. Much more performant than Unregister/Register pattern!

members.member: Weather this material has layers.

Important!
Due to the geometry in question the slope is stored as the cosine (used in dot product).
Meanwhile the dot product for the latitude yields the cosine of the modulus of the compliment of our angle. This means after the maths are done that what we have is the *sine*, so the latitude is stored as the sine.

member.name: T:VRage.Game.VisualScripting.MyVisualScriptBuilder
member.summary:
Creates class syntax for provided file.
Notes: WorldScripts Consist of Event methods having only input purpose, so they have no output variables and void return value. One event type with same signature can appear on multiple places in the script. Such situaltion mean that the method body will have multiple sections that will be later evaluated independently without any order dependency.
NormalScripts Should have only one input as entry point of the method and multiple or none Output nodes. Output nodes have parameters defined. Method signature will contain input variables (from input node), output variables (from outputs - all outputs must have same signature) and bool return value. Return value tells the system if the output node was reached and whenever we should or should not continue executing the sequence chain.

member.name: M:VRage.Game.Voxels.IMyStorage.Pin
member.summary:
Pin the storage.
While the storage is pinned it will not be closed, but calls to pin will mark it to close as soon as all pins are disposed.
The pin might not be valid if the storage was already closed. You should always check once you pin the storage that the pin is valid.
member.returns: A storage pin. Must be disposed when no longer in use.

members.member:
Lod controller for voxel meshes implemented in the fashion of the classic clipmap paper.
The original paper: https://web.archive.org/web/20160428150805/http://www.cs.virginia.edu/~gfx/Courses/2002/BigData/papers/Texturing/Clipmap.pdf
This implementation extends the ideas presented in the paper to 3 dimensions and manages a mesh 'sewing' process that joins the boundaries between meshes.

members.member:
Cell cached used by this clipmap. Can be null.
The clipmap uses this cache both for storing recently used meshes in case they may be needed again and also when pre-fetching. If no cache is provided pre-fetching will be disabled.

Cell render updates are queued because they deal with render data. As a result we must process them on the render thread.

members.member:
Manages a clipmap ring.
The clipmap is comprised of concentric 'rings' (actually they are thick walled boxes, but the original paper calls the rings in the 2D case).
Each ring contains meshes of a specific level of detail.

member.name: M:VRage.Voxels.Clipmap.MyVoxelClipmapRing.AddCell(VRageMath.Vector3I)
member.summary:
Introduce a new cell.
Newly added cells are calculated, stitched and then post-processed so they can be rendered.
New cells need time to be constructed, as a result they are placed as dependencies for the parent cell which invariably needs to be removed, but will do so only when all children are ready.

Remove the cell right away.
This method is separated from finish remove so we can have more control over what code paths can modify cells at which times.

member.name: M:VRage.Voxels.DualContouring.MyDualContouringMesher.Calculate(VRage.Entities.Components.MyVoxelMesherComponent,System.Int32,VRageMath.Vector3I,VRageMath.Vector3I,VRage.Voxels.MyStorageDataTypeFlags,VRage.Voxels.MyVoxelRequestFlags,VRage.Voxels.VrVoxelMesh)
member.summary:
Calculate a voxel mesh.
Given the size sz of the range requested the resulting mesh will have sz -1 vertices (given it's dual nature), and sz -2 quads 9given that quads are dual to vertices.
member.param: The Voxel mesher entity component responsible for this request.
The starting range in voxels for the request.
Which properties are to be computed.
Request flags to pass onto the data request performed by the contour.
Mesh to store results into, this mesh will be cleared regardless of the result being empty.

member.name: M:VRage.Voxels.DualContouring.MyDualContouringMesher.GenerateQuads(System.Byte,System.UInt16[],System.Collections.Generic.List{VRage.Game.Voxels.MyVoxelQuad})
member.summary:
Given a vertex configuration determine the quads required to correctly connect those vertices.
To build a cube mask: - assign every vertex in a cube an index equal to its (x,y,z) (dot) (1, 2, 4). - for every corner that has a positive sign, assign the mask bit given by it's index to one. - leave remaining bits in the mask assigned to 0.

member.name: F:VRage.Voxels.DualContouring.MyDualContouringMesher.EdgeTable
member.summary:
Tells based on a cube iso-configuration which edges are crossed by the isosurface
The standard MC table and diagrams from the original implementations and papers index the cube indices as a rotation in the xy plane: Namely the indices for (0,0), (1,0), (0,1) and (1,1) being 0, 1, 3 and 2 repectivelly.
This can be confusing in many cases where one would expect a mo0re traditional Z curve order. So the table here was re ordered in Z order.
Here is a good page about marching cubes. http://paulbourke.net/geometry/polygonise/

members.member:

Intersect line with storage.

The offsets are normalised.

member.name: F:MyCommonTexts.General_Experimental
member.summary: Game may break because Experimental Mode is enabled. It contains many experimental, unofficial and not fully developed features. These were the features that we added to the game throughout its Early Access development, but are now not considered to be an official part of the game. However, we don't want to remove them from the game because many players are used to them. Therefore by default, you are in safe mode with only selected features and limits. Experimental mode was introduced because we want to guarantee flawless gameplay, but we can only do this if we control the boundaries. Mods, unsafe settings, or unofficial features are out of range of what we can guarantee.

member.name: F:MyCommonTexts.Campaign_Congratulation_Text
member.summary: Were proud to present you with this Veteran Engineer Suit. Wear it with honour. A Veteran Badge has also been added to your main menu to remind you of all your achievements. As a true Space Engineer, its now up to you how far you will push yourself to create, explore and build across the stars. There are still many adventures to experience and challenges to overcome. Good luck!

member.name: F:MyCommonTexts.SimpleNewGame_Creative_Description
member.summary: Creative mode. Dont feel like gathering materials, planning logistics? Let your imagination run wild and jump into creative mode! Build gigantic starships and many other types of vehicles, or perhaps you'd like to construct a space elevator? The choice is yours. There is no health in creative mode.

member.name: F:MyCommonTexts.SimpleNewGame_LearningToSurvive_Description
member.summary: Restore an old outpost to act as your base of operations and explore the remains of what a once thriving industry left behind. Learn about space engineering or pick a fight, the choice is yours, this is where your career begins!

member.name: F:MyCommonTexts.SimpleNewGame_NeverSurrender_Description
member.summary: Survival mode. Start your own space journey. Gather resources, create components and build something truly epic. Discover new challenges and engineer solutions. Explore planets, fly to the moon, navigate space or drill a hole to the center of the Earth. Its up to you!

member.name: F:MyCommonTexts.SimpleNewGame_TheFirstJump_Description
member.summary: This scenario offers a linear story with action-packed gameplay, while the majority of Space Engineers scenarios feature unique sandbox environments where players create their own challenges.
